title: 113_s2439
content: The Act may be cited as the "NSA Internal Watchdog Act" and establishes an Inspector General for the National Security Agency. The "NSA Internal Watchdog Act" amends the Inspector General Act of 1978 to elevate the status of the Inspector General of the National Security Agency. The President must nominate a person for this role within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The National Security Agency's Inspector General, appointed under the Inspector General Act of 1978, can continue serving until the President appoints a replacement. They will maintain their current pay and responsibilities during this period. The Inspector General Act of 1978 is amended to include a review of mechanisms for reporting complaints at the National Security Agency. Additionally, special provisions concerning the National Security Agency are outlined in a new section. The General Counsel to the Inspector General of the National Security Agency is appointed by the Inspector General and serves as the chief legal officer. They provide legal services exclusively to the Inspector General, perform prescribed functions, and serve at the Inspector General's discretion. The Office of the General Counsel may appoint legal counsel as needed. The Inspector General of the National Security Agency can appoint legal counsel as staff of the General Counsel. The Inspector General is authorized to compel testimony from former employees, contractors, or detailees through subpoenas enforceable by the court. The Inspector General must notify the Attorney General before issuing any subpoena. Prohibitions on investigations for national security reasons are evaluated within a specific timeframe. The Inspector General of the National Security Agency must evaluate prohibitions on investigations for national security reasons within a specific timeframe. This evaluation includes submitting reports to relevant committees and documenting instances where the Secretary of Defense prohibited audits or investigations. The Inspector General is restricted from conducting audits or investigations during the specified period. When evaluating surveillance programs, the Inspector General must consider their impact on civil rights, effectiveness, and any recommendations for improvement. Reports to Congress must be accessible to all Members of Congress. SEC. 5. AUDIT OF SURVEILLANCE PROGRAMS AND BACKGROUND INVESTIGATIONS. The Inspector General of the National Security Agency will conduct a comprehensive audit of surveillance programs, interactions with the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act court, and background investigations for NSA employees. The Inspector General of the National Security Agency will conduct an audit on surveillance programs, interactions with the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act court, and background investigations for NSA employees. A report will be submitted to the House and Senate Intelligence Committees within 180 days of the Inspector General's appointment. This does not affect the Inspector General's ongoing responsibility to audit NSA surveillance programs and background investigations.
